thread.title: Investors Snub Treasuries for Higher-Yielding U.S. Corporates
thread.title_full: Investors Snub Treasuries for Higher-Yielding U.S. Corporates - Bloomberg Business

author: Susanne Walker Barton
title: Investors Snub Treasuries for Higher-Yielding U.S. Corporates
text:
Treasuries dropped as investors seek to buy higher-yielding corporate debt, rebuffing government securities at a time when the Federal Reserve is set to raise interest rates.
Thirty-year bonds led losses as Intel Corp. is forecast to sell as much as $9 billion in debt this week to back its purchase of Altera Corp. Investors are starting to believe in a September rate increase as futures show a 42 percent chance the Fed will raise borrowing costs during that month, up from 35 percent a week ago, as Greece’s bailout agreement clears one of the obstacles to higher rates.
“It’s been a pretty solid corporate calendar and we’ve seen that weigh on the market as investors swap out and leave Treasuries for higher-yielding corporates,” said Larry Milstein, managing director in New York of government-debt trading at R.W. Pressprich & Co.
Thirty-year bond yields rose four basis points, or 0.04 percentage point, to 3.14 percent as of 9:05 a.m. in New York, according to Bloomberg Bond Trader data. The price of the 3 percent security maturing in May 2045 declined 3/4, or $7.50 per $1,000 face amount, to 97 3/8.
U.S. corporate bond yields were at 4.1 percent Monday, according to Bank of America Merrill Lynch Indexes.
